newsitem.title: UK: Rolls-Royce says to solve aero engine problem.
newsitem.headline: Rolls-Royce says to solve aero engine problem.

text.p: British aero-engine manufacturer Rolls-Royce Plc said on Friday it had identified the technical problem with its Trent 700 engines that forced a Hong Kong Dragon Airlines (Dragonair) Airbus 330 to make an emergency landing in the Phillippines on Friday.
"We have identified the problem and we are working closely with our customers to sort it out," a company spokeswoman in London told Reuters.
The Dragonair pilot was forced to land on one engine after Flight KA-MH061, carrying 127 passengers, from Hong Kong developed an engine fault en route to Kota Kinabalu in Malaysia.
The Dragonair landing was the latest in a series of recent forced landings involving Airbus 300s using Trent 700 engines.
She said the problem was in the gearbox bearings in the Trent 700 engines. "We are replacing the affected parts," the spokeswoman said.
The pilot had to shut off the engine after it developed an oil pressure problem. "The problem posed no danger to passengers or to the aircraft," she said.
Airport officials in Manila confimed that none of the passengers or flight crew members were hurt.
The Rolls-Royce official said there was no reason to pull out the engines saying the problem should be rectified and the solutions tested within a month.
Problems with gearbox bearings in Trent 700 engines have forced Hong Kong's leading carrier Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd Airbus 330-300s to make a series of unscheduled single-engine landings recently.

A Cathay Pacific plane with Trent 700 engines made a single-engine landing at Bangkok last week. Two weeks ago a flight to the Philippines had to return to Hong Kong, a Cathay Pacific spokesman told Reuters in Hong Kong on Wednesday.
The Rolls-Royce official said it was the same problem which had forced these landings.
The Trent 700 engine was introduced in March 1995 and apart from Cathay Pacific and Dragonair, they are also used by Indonesian carrier Garuda Indonesia.
The company said orders for at least 60 such engines were in place from other leading airlines including TWA, Gulf Air and Emirates Air.
